Description: A hollow terracotta standing figure of a female saint or beneficent demon, with a triangular wreath framing her hair. No arms are indicated, just smooth bulges at the shoulder; her breasts are not shown. A long tunic may be worn, with clavi indicated by painted verticals. She wears a double choker necklace (or garlands), with another necklace below, and has a further long necklace with a circular pendant hanging below her breasts. Two holes are pieced through, from front to back, one on each side of her neck. The back is plain, except for a small raised circle low down. Two-piece mould. Pink Aswan kaolinite clay with a whitish surface and a yellow slip overall. Details in fired-on black and red ceramic colours.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Earl of Belmore. Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Near those of registration no. 1926,0520.16, above. Bibliog: Perhaps Belmore 1843: pl. 2, between nos 68 and 69. Being studied by Hesham Abdel-Qader in view of publication
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3394)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
